title: How to Make Natural Scented Candles With Essential Oils

steps.title: Choose a heatproof container for your candles.
steps.content: Choose a heatproof container for your candles. Choose a metal, ceramic, or glass vessel because they’ll hold up to the hot wax and heat from burning your candle the best. It could be a bowl, mug, cup, or any other solid container you have at home. You may even use a container from an old candle you recently burned. Just be sure to wash out any debris inside and dry the container off before using it. [1] X Research source To check if your container is heatproof, fill it with boiling water and let it sit for 2–3 minutes. Then, pour out the hot water and immediately fill the container with cold water. If the container cracks or gets damaged, then choose a different one for making your candle. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Melt soy wax flakes in a double boiler.
steps.content: Melt soy wax flakes in a double boiler . Fill the bottom pot of your double boiler halfway with water and place it over high heat. Then, fill up your candle container twice with the wax flakes and pour them all into the top pot of your double boiler. Place the pot with the wax on top of the one with the water so the wax can melt without the risk of it burning. [3] X Research source Weigh the wax you’re using on a kitchen scale before melting it so you know how much you’re using. This will make mixing fragrances easier later on. Alternatively, you may use beeswax , which already has a natural honey scent. However, beeswax doesn’t hold additional fragrances as well as soy. Avoid using paraffin wax for making candles. Even though paraffin holds scent the best, it’s made from petroleum and can release chemicals and soot deposits into the air. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Add essential oils to the wax when it reaches 185 °F (85 °C).
steps.content: Add essential oils to the wax when it reaches 185 °F (85 °C). Check the melted wax with a candy thermometer until the wax reaches the correct temperature. Once the wax is hot and ready, add about 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of your favorite essential oil for every 4 ounces (110 g) of wax to naturally scent your candles . Pour the oil into the melted wax and stir it together with a chopstick. [5] X Research source Commercial fragrance oils have stronger scents, so only use 1 fluid ounce (30 mL) for every 1 pound (450 g) of wax. Just be aware these oils may have synthetic compounds that are released into the air when you burn them. [6] X Research source If you want to dye your candle a different color, add 3–4 drops of candle dye at a time to the melted wax and fragrance. Dip a piece of white paper into the wax and let it dry to see how the color will turn out. [7] X Research source Avoid adding more fragrance to your candle because too much may prevent it from burning properly.

steps.title: Attach a wick to the bottom of your container with a wick sticker.
steps.content: Attach a wick to the bottom of your container with a wick sticker . Start with a wick that’s longer than the container height. Take the backing off of a wick sticker and place it onto the metal bottom of the wick. Place the wick’s metal piece centered in the bottom of your container, and press it down firmly so it stays in place. Lay a popsicle stick or pencil across the top of the container, and wrap the loose end of the wick around it so it doesn’t fall down. [8] X Research source If your container is larger than 3 1 ⁄ 2 inches (8.9 cm) in diameter, use multiple wicks to burn the candle evenly . Alternatively, dab some hot glue or melted wax onto the bottom of the wick instead of a sticker to attach it to your container. If you can’t easily reach the bottom of your container, then push the metal piece down using a pencil or chopstick so it adheres firmly.

steps.title: Pour the wax into the container once it cools to 135 °F (57 °C).
steps.content: Pour the wax into the container once it cools to 135 °F (57 °C). Take the melted wax off of the heat and let it cool down so it sets properly inside of the container without leaving gaps. Check the temperature of the wax every few minutes with your thermometer. Once it cools to 135 °F (57 °C), slowly pour the melted wax into the container, leaving about 1 ⁄ 2 –1 inch (1.3–2.5 cm) of space between the wax and lip. [9] X Research source Lay old newspapers down over your work surface so you can easily clean off the candle wax if you accidentally spill. Try adding natural scented ingredients to the candle after pouring it. You could add dried flowers, crushed herbs, cinnamon sticks, or cloves for added scents and decoration. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Trim the wicks down to 1⁄4 in (0.64 cm) after 24 hours.
steps.content: Trim the wicks down to 1 ⁄ 4 in (0.64 cm) after 24 hours. Let the wax completely harden and set for 24 hours after pouring your candle so air bubbles don’t form. When the wax has dried and solidified, unwrap the end of the wick from the pencil or popsicle stick. Use a pair of scissors to cut the wick down to size so it burns properly. [11] X Research source Alternatively, use a wick trimmer , which is made specifically to reach into candle containers to cut the wick shorter.

steps.title: Lavender
steps.content: Lavender The refreshing smell of lavender essential oil creates a more relaxing space in your home, and it can help reduce any stress you’re feeling. Dried lavender petals also add a natural scent and a beautiful look to your candle. [12] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Cinnamon
steps.content: Cinnamon If you want your home to have an inviting fall aroma, try making your candle with cinnamon essential oil as the base. Add in ground cinnamon or fresh cinnamon sticks to the wax while it’s still solidifying for added decor and scents. [13] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Peppermint
steps.content: Peppermint When you want a cool, minty smell around your home, add in peppermint essential oil to your candle. Peppermint can help reduce stress and improve your focus, so it’s perfect to add ambiance and use around the hectic winter holiday months. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Citrus
steps.content: Citrus When you’re looking for a bright, fresh-smelling scent, a citrus essential oil will smell great throughout the year and help boost your mood. You could get a general citrus oil, or opt for a specific scent like lemon , grapefruit , or orange . Add in dried citrus rinds as the wax cools for even more natural scents. [15] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Vanilla
steps.content: Vanilla Vanilla essential oils are both relaxing and uplifting, so they’re great for boosting your mood when you burn candles made with them. If you want your home to smell like fresh, sweet baked goods, vanilla is the perfect choice for you. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Rosemary
steps.content: Rosemary If you love the smell of fresh greens and want a fresh herbal scent around your home, then mix in rosemary oil into the candle wax. Rosemary may also help boost your mood and reduce stress. Sprinkle a bit of dried rosemary into the wax before it hardens completely for an even stronger aroma. [17] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Eucalyptus
steps.content: Eucalyptus Eucalyptus essential oil has a very calming and relaxing scent, so it’s perfect on its own or mixed with another oil, like lavender. Eucalyptus can also act as an insect repellent, so burning a candle outdoors may keep the pests away. [18] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Citronella
steps.content: Citronella Citronella oil works best as an insect repellent because bugs dislike the strong scent. If you want to enjoy time out on a deck or patio but don’t want to deal with pests, make and burn a citronella candle to take care of the problem.
